case_name: Rai Bahadur P. Banerjee v. Income Tax Department

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 486 of 1962 filed by special leave from Patna High Court judgment dated September 24, 1959 in Miscellaneous Judicial Case No. 318 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 486 of 1962. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 24, 1959, of the Patna High Court in Miscella

facts.text: Appeal heard and judgment delivered on March 27, 1963 by HIDAYATULLAH J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. March 27. The judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH J.-This is an assessees appeal by special leave of this Court against an order of the High Court of Patna

facts.text: Original assessee Rai Bahadur P. Banerjee is dead; his son substituted in his place also died during pendency in High Court; present appeal by widow of son and other legal representatives.

anchor.surface_text: This is an assessees appeal by special leave of this Court against an order of the High Court of Patna, answering in favour of the Department the question whether in the circumstances of the case the amount of Rs. 51,000 being the value of high denomination numberes encashed by the assessee, has been validly taxed as profits from some undisclosed business. The original assessee, Rai Bahadur P. Banerjee, is dead.- His son, who was substituted in his place, also died during the pendency of the proceedings in the High Court. The present appeal has been filed by the widow of the son and other legal representatives.

facts.text: Banerjee was owner of several collieries in Jharia Coal fields in Bihar and contractor for raising coal.

anchor.surface_text: Banerjee was the owner of several companylieries in the Jharia Coal fields in the State of Bihar and was also a companytractor for raising companyl. This matter relates to the assessment year 1946-47.

facts.text: Assessment year 1946-47; Banerjee originally assessed on income of Rs. 1,28,738.

anchor.surface_text: This matter relates to the assessment year 1946-47. For that year, Banerjee was assessed on an income of Rs. 1,28,738. The assessment was then re-opened under s. 34 of the Indian Income-Tax Act, and was enhanced, but subsequently on appeal, it was reduced to a sum a little below the original assessment.

facts.text: Assessment reopened under s.34, enhanced, then reduced on appeal to below original.

anchor.surface_text: The assessment was then re-opened under s. 34 of the Indian Income-Tax Act, and was enhanced, but subsequently on appeal, it was reduced to a sum a little below the original assessment. The present assessment was made on a second re-opening of the case under s. 34 in the following circumstances.

facts.text: On January 22, 1946, Banerjee encashed high denomination notes of Rs. 51,000.

anchor.surface_text: On January 22, 1946, Banerjee encashed high denomination numberes of the value of Rs. 51,000/-. In his application under the Ordinance which demonetized high denomination numberes, Banerjee gave the reason for the possession of the numberes as follows-

facts.text: Banerjee's explanation: engaged in colliery proprietor, contractor under Kilburn & Co. as H.P. Banerjee & Son, and State Rly Bokaro Swang Hazaribagh as Jharia Dhanbad Coal Mica Mining Co; kept large sums for weekly payments to labour 30-40 thousand; floating capital not profit.

anchor.surface_text: I am engaged in business as companyliery proprie- tor, companytractor under Messrs. Kilburn Co. in the name and style of H.P. Banerjee Son and also under the State Rly. Bokaro, Swang, Hazaribagh district in the name of Jharia Dhanbad Coal Mica Mining Co For companyducting the business and payment to labour, I have to pay every week between 30/40 thousand as I did number get payment for work done every week. I had to keep large sum of money to meet emergency It is neither profit number part of profit-it is very floating capital for purpose of companyducing business. It is number an excess of profit.

facts.text: Banerjee had accounts with Imperial Bank of India, Nath Bank Ltd. Jharia, Central Bank of India Ltd. Bhowanipore Branch; did not remember from which bank notes came.

anchor.surface_text: He stated that he had accounts with  1  Imperial Bank of India,  2  Nath Bank Ltd., jharia, and  3  Central Bank of India Ltd., Bhowanipore Branch, but added that he did number remember exactly from which Bank the numberes came into his possession, as his transanctions were frequent.

facts.text: Notice under s.34 not questioned; Banerjee's explanation not accepted by ITO.

anchor.surface_text: The numberice which was issued to him under s. 34 of the Income Tax Act, was number questioned on any of the grounds which are usual in such cases. Banerjees explanation was number accepted.

facts.text: ITO found no central account for bank withdrawals/remittances; none of books contained bank account; discrepancy of nearly Rs.50,000 in statements.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer pointed out that although his business was large and the withdrawals from the various banks were large and frequent, he had number maintained a central account showing withdrawals from the banks and remittances made to his various businesses, and that numbere of the books maintained by the assessee and produced by him, companytained a bank account. The Income Tax Officer found a discrepancy of nearly Rs. 50,000 in the statements filed by the assessee.

facts.text: ITO treated Rs.51,000 HDNs as profits from undisclosed source and assessed as income.

anchor.surface_text: He, accordingly, treated the high denomination numberes as profits from some undisclosed source and assessed them as assessable income.

facts.text: Appeals to AAC and Tribunal upheld ITO order.

anchor.surface_text: Banerjee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and further to the Tribunal. Both the authorities upheld the order of the Income Tax Officer.

facts.text: High Court directed statement of case on question whether Rs.51,000 validly taxed as undisclosed profits; answered in favour of Department.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee demanded a case which was refused, but the High Court directed a statement of the case on the question already quoted. The High Court decided the question against the assessee, and hence this appeal.

facts.text: Assessee claimed cash balance Rs.1,62,022 later corrected to Rs.1,21,875 before AAC.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the assessee claimed that the high denomination numberes were a part of the cash balance at the head office. The Income Tax Officer found that at first the cash on hand was said to be Rs. 1,62,022, but on scrutiny, it was found to be wrong. Indeed, the assessee himself companyrected it before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and stated there that the balance was Rs. 1,21,875.

facts.text: Books did not contain bank entries; no central account for transfers; no account of personal expenses.

anchor.surface_text: Ordinarily, this would have prima facie proved that the assessee might have kept a portion of this balance in high denomination numberes. But the assessee failed to prove this balance, as books of the assessee did number companytain entries in respect of banks. Though cash used to be received from banks and sent to the various places where works were carried on and vice versa, numbercentral account of such transfers was disclosed. There was also numberaccount of personal expenses of the assessee

facts.text: On day HDNs encashed, Rs.45,000 drawn by cheque; next remittance Rs.16,000 to Bokaro but Rs.17,000 withdrawn few days before; Rs.8,000 day later, Rs.20,000 ten days later; Rs.45,000 untouched; Rs.6,000 withdrawn Jan 30 not utilized, totaling Rs.51,000.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner also went into the question and found that on the same day when the high denomination numberes were encashed, a sum of Rs. 45,000 was drawn by cheque. The next remittance immediately afterwards was of Rs. 16,000 to Bokaro, but Rs. 17,000 were withdrawn a few days before to meet this expense. A withdrawal of Rs. 8,000 was made a day later and Rs. 20,000 were withdrawn ten days later to finance the business. It appears that the money on hand  Rs. 45,000  was number touched at all, but on January 30, 1946, a further sum of Rs. 6,000 was withdrawn and number utilized, which made up the sum of Rs. 51,000 for which the high denomination numberes were encashed.

facts.text: Tribunal held HDNs represented not cash balance but unexplained money from undisclosed source.

anchor.surface_text: On these facts, the Tribunal came to the companyclusion that the high denomination numberes represented number the cash balance but some other money which remained unexplained, and the Tribunal treatted it as income from some undisclosed source.

facts.text: High Court held materials show Rs.51,000 not part of cash balance, source not proved, justified as assessable undisclosed income.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held on the above facts and circumstances that there were materials to show that Rs. 51,000 did number form part of the cash balance, and the source of money number having been satisfactorily proved, the Department was justified in holding it to be assessable income of the assessee from some undisclosed source.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld High Court conclusion that Rs.51,000 is assessable income from undisclosed source.

anchor.surface_text: In this companyclusion, the High Court was justified, regard being had to the principles we have explained above.

facts.text: Proceedings under s.34 validly commenced; no special burden on Department beyond ordinary assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The argument that as this was a case under s. 34 of the Income Tax Act, it cast a special burden on the Department to show that this income had escaped earlier, need number detain us. No doubt, proceedings under s. 34 can only be companymenced under the companyditions prescribed in the section, but when the proceedings are validly companymenced, there is numberdifference between an ordinary assessment and an additional assessment under s. 34, and the same rule as to burden of proof governs the additional assessment.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated September 24, 1959, of the Patna High Court in Miscellaneous judicial Case No. 318 of 1957.

This is an assessees appeal by special leave of this Court against an order of the High Court of Patna, answering in favour of the Department the question whether in the circumstances of the case the amount of Rs. 51,000
re-opened under s. 34 of the Indian Income-Tax Act, and was enhanced, but subsequently on appeal, it was reduced to a sum a little below the original assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The connection of the appellants is that since the Department had issued a notice under s. 34 of the Income Tax Act, it was incumbent on the department to establish that the amount in question was income which had escaped assessment. The appellants also contend that even if the assessee was required to prove the source of the high denomination notes, he had sufficiently proved it by showing that he had large amounts on hand, which were held for convenience in high denomination notes.

concepts.interpretation: Assessee must prove source of receipt and that it does not bear character of income; if fails, ITO can infer income from disclosed or undisclosed source. In HDN cases, proof of large cash balance sufficient prima facie if reasonable to hold in HDNs; Department must rebut.

concepts.unlisted_description: Burden on assessee to explain source and nature of money received, especially HDNs

anchor.surface_text: In these cases in which the assessee proved that he had on the relevant date a large sum of money sufficient to cover the number of notes encashed, this Court and the High Courts, in the absence of something which showed that the explanation was inherently improbable, accepted the explanation that the assessee held the amount or a part of it in high denomination notes. In other words, in such cases, the assessee was held prima facie to have discharged the burden which was upon him.

concepts.interpretation: Proof of sufficient cash balance constitutes prima facie discharge of burden if reasonable for HDNs

anchor.surface_text: Where the assessee was unable to prove that in his normal business or otherwise, he was possessed of so much cash, it was held that the assessee started under a cloud and must dispel that cloud to the reasonable satisfaction of the assessing authorities, and that if he did not, then, the Department was free to reject his explanation

concepts.interpretation: Assessee must prove explanation to reasonable satisfaction of authorities

issues.text: whether in the circumstances of the case the amount of Rs. 51,000 being the value of high denomination notes encashed by the assessee, has been validly taxed as profits from some undisclosed business

anchor.surface_text: This is an assessees appeal by special leave of this Court against an order of the High Court of Patna, answering in favour of the Department the question whether in the circumstances of the case the amount of Rs. 51,000 being the value of high denomination notes encashed by the assessee, has been validly taxed as profits from some undisclosed business.

issues.text: whether, since the Department had issued a notice under s. 34 of the Income Tax Act, it was incumbent on the department to establish that the amount in question was income which had escaped assessment

anchor.surface_text: The connection of the appellants is that since the Department had issued a notice under s. 34 of the Income Tax Act, it was incumbent on the department to establish that the amount in question was income which had escaped assessment. The appellants also contend that even if the assessee was required to prove the source of the high denomination notes, he had sufficiently proved it by showing that he had large amounts on hand, which were held for convenience in high denomination notes.

issues.text: whether the assessee was required to prove the source of the high denomination notes and, if so, whether he had sufficiently proved it by showing that he had large amounts on hand, which were held for convenience in high denomination notes

anchor.surface_text: The appellants also contend that even if the assessee was required to prove the source of the high denomination notes, he had sufficiently proved it by showing that he had large amounts on hand, which were held for convenience in high denomination notes. The appellants thus submit that the burden, if any, upon the assessee was discharged in the case, and the evidence being unrebutted, the additional assessment could not be made.

arguments.claim: If assessee fails to prove source and nature of receipt, ITO entitled to infer it is assessable income from disclosed or undisclosed source

anchor.surface_text: Where the assessee was unable to prove... the assessee started under a cloud... From the last two cases, it is plain that if there is receipt of an amount... incumbent upon the assessee to show that it does not bear the character of income.

arguments.claim: In HDN cases with proved large cash balance sufficient to cover notes and no inherent improbability, assessee prima facie discharges burden

anchor.surface_text: In these cases in which the assessee proved that he had on the relevant date a large sum of money sufficient to cover the number of notes encashed... accepted the explanation... assessee was held prima facie to have discharged the burden

arguments.claim: Assessee failed to prove cash balance: books lack bank entries, no central transfers account, no personal expenses account, unexplained large sums despite bank accounts at sites

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, the assessee claimed... cash on hand was said to be Rs. 1,62,022... corrected to Rs.1,21,875. Ordinarily... But the assessee failed to prove this balance, as books of the assessee did not contain entries in respect of banks.

arguments.claim: Specific transactions show Rs.45,000 cheque drawn same day untouched, subsequent withdrawals totaling Rs.51,000 unused, indicating HDNs not from cash balance

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner also went into the question and found that on the same day... Rs. 45,000 was drawn by cheque. The next remittance... Rs. 45,000 was not touched... which made up the sum of Rs. 51,000

arguments.claim: Lalchand case distinguished: there almirah account genuine, large cash need proved, bank statements supported; here defects in accounts and transactions rebut explanation

anchor.surface_text: We now come to Lalchand Bhagats case... This Court did not hold that the assessee need not prove anything. As we have said earlier, the burden of proof must depend on the facts of the case.

holdings.text: In this conclusion, the High Court was justified, regard being had to the principles we have explained above.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee failed to prove cash balance due to absence of bank entries, no central transfer account, transaction discrepancies showing untouched funds matching HDN amount, rebutting prima facie case.

holdings.text: when the proceedings are validly commenced, there is no difference between an ordinary assessment and an additional assessment under s. 34, and the same rule as to burden of proof governs the additional assessment.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Notice under s.34 not questioned; once validly initiated, burden same as ordinary assessment; no special proof required that income escaped earlier.

holdings.text: if there is receipt of an amount in the accounting year, it is incumbent in the first instance upon the assessee to show that it does not bear the character of income. If he fails to do this, the Income Tax Officer may hold that it represents income of the assessee either from the sources he has disclosed or from some undisclosed source.

anchor.surface_text: From the last two cases, it is plain that if there is receipt of an amount in the accounting year, it is incumbent in the first instance upon the assessee to show that it does not bear the character of income. If he fails to

holdings.reasoning_summary: Drawing from precedents like Govindaraju Mudaliar and Manindranath Das; assessee bears initial burden to prove source and non-income nature of receipt.

holdings.text: In cases of high denomination notes, where the business and the state of accounts and dealings of the assessee justify a reasonable inference that he might have for convenience kept the whole or a part of a particular sum in high denomination notes, the assessee prima facie discharges his initial burden when he proves the balance and that it might reasonably have been kept in high denomination notes.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applying principles to HDN encashment; proof of sufficient balance + reasonableness prima facie suffices unless rebutted by defects or contrary evidence.

holdings.text: We do not think that the Allahabad view puts no burden upon the assessee and throws the entire burden on the Department. The case itself does not bear this out. If it does, then, it is not the right view.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects interpretation of Kanpur Steel placing entire burden on Department; correct law requires assessee's initial proof; Allahabad not approved on that point.

holdings.text: The assessee failed to prove this balance, as books of the assessee did not contain entries in respect of banks... There was also no account of personal expenses of the assessee.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific factual defects in accounts (no bank entries, no central transfers, no personal expenses) prevent prima facie proof despite claimed balance.

precedents.case_name: Kanpur Steel Co Ltd v CIT
precedents.cited_proposition: burden lay upon the Department to prove suppressed income; no burden on assessee to show source pre-demonetization
precedents.cited_holding: explanation fairly satisfactory; cannot conjecture accumulation of notes

Commissioner of Income Tax, Bihar Orissa  1 , the tax-payer had encashed Notes of the value of Rs. 28,600, which he companytended were his accumulated savings. His explanation was accepted in respect of Rs. 15,000,  1   1955  27 I.T.R. 522.

precedents.cited_holding: explanation rejected for part where not traced

precedents.case_name: A Govindaraju Mudaliar v CIT Hyderabad
precedents.cited_proposition: if assessee fails to prove source and nature of receipt, ITO entitled to infer assessable nature
precedents.cited_holding: open to hold credits represented concealed income
